Award.AwardTitle: Scanning Electrochemical Microscopy and Ultramicroelectrode Studies Electrochemistry of Single Molecules and Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program is supporting the research of Allen J. Bard of the University of Texas at Austin to continue his development of a special type of microscope. The instrument, which uses a technique known as scanning electrochemical microscopy, or SECM, has been developed in the investigator's lab over a number of years and utilizes a tiny electrified probe hovered just above the sample of interest. As this probe is moved across the surface, electrical signals are detected through it and an image of the sample surface revealed. The current project is investigating various types of electrified tips, or ultramicroelectrodes, interacting with different types of surfaces, including very soft ones. such as emulsions. The work is having a broad impact through the direct development of new scientific instrumentation that will find application in a wide variety of fields from biology to manufacturing. It is having a further broad impact on the training of the next generation of scientists through the participation of student researchers in the project.

The central thrust of this project is the development of further extensions of the SECM method and improved fundamental understanding of single nanoparticle events. This is accomplished by the detection and measurement of collisions between different types of single nanoparticles (NPs) and a variety of electrodes. New areas of electrochemical study in this work include: (1) Improved and advanced understanding of NP responses; (2) Investigation of new NP systems, e.g. soft particles, by the collision technique; and (3) Application of tunneling layers with nm-size ultramicroelectrodes (UMEs) with the ability to characterize large molecules by collision measurements. Knowledge gained from this work regarding the nature of nanoparticle/surface interactions at electrodes can reveal subtle phenomena not observable in ensemble studies, such as the effects of current density variations across UME surfaces, motion of particles on surfaces, deactivation effects by trace impurity adsorption, and single nanoparticle dynamics. Stochastic electrochemistry could potentially challenge current understanding of inner-sphere heterogeneous electron transfer, and provide a pathway to advances in inter-conversion of chemical and electrical energy. The experiments being carried out are providing new insights and a novel tool for the study of emulsions, micelles and vesicles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI continued development of scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM), a technique first pioneered in the Pl's laboratory, and which has been improved and applied to many fields by researchers around the world. This project focused on nanometer-size tips and high resolution scanning. The project achieved improved fundamental understanding of the interaction of single nanoparticles with electrodes (i.e., collision events). New areas of electrochemical studies included an improved and advanced understanding of the detailed current and potential response during nanoparticle (NP) collisions, investigation of new NP systems by the collision technique (e.g. soft particles such as emulsions, vesicles, and micelles), and investigation of tunneling layers to create nanoscale ultramicroelectrodes (UME) with the ability to characterize large molecules by collision measurements.

The intellectual merit of the project was demonstrated through the potential to change the way in which challenges in electrochemistry can be addressed. Single molecule and particle chemistry are active research areas involving comparison of results obtained from single molecule studies with those of the more familiar ensemble investigations. This project demonstrated that phenomena not observable in ensemble studies could be studied, such as the effects of current density variations across UME surfaces, motion of particles on surfaces, and deactivation effects by trace impurity adsorption. This understanding was advanced through better characterization of NPs by single NP tracking techniques, improved preparation of monodisperse NPs, and characterization of solution purity. The project also extended the collision technique to studies of many new and different types of NPs, with the potential for new approaches to characterizing colloidal systems, and new insights with potential applications to biological systems and the wide variety of emulsion applications. The project demonstrated that the capture of a single metal NP on an electrode surface provides a method for production of nanometer sized electrodes to extend collision experiments and SECM applications. The method of collisions by electrocatalytic amplification developed by the PI?s group was used to build catalytic structures atom-by-atom. These fundamental insights were shown to be important in tailoring the formation of catalyst centers and in driving electroanalysis down to the femtomolar regime.

Stochastic electrochemistry pursued in this project broadly challenged current understanding of inner-sphere heterogeneous electron transfer, and provided a pathway to advances in interconversion of chemical and electrical energy. Results of the project broadly advanced capabilities for highly sensitive electrochemical detection, which are both transformative and aligned with commercial needs for sensors and analytical tools with higher sensitivity and selectivity, lower cost, and ease of use. Although approaches in the project were fundamental and driven primarily toward broad advancement of scientific knowledge, the research outcomes transferred to industry. In fact, SECM instruments have already become commercially available from several companies, and that industry has grown from previous research in the Pl's lab. The project broadly contributed to development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce where excellent opportunities were provided for the training of young chemists who participated in hands-on, multidisciplinary scientific research in areas of national importance.
